context: [2] is: Kenji Matsui (matsui{at}yamaguchi-u.ac.jp). [1] â†µ1 This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Sciences KAKENHI (grant nos. [2] 26660095 and 25282234) and the Yobimizu Project from Yamaguchi University. Due to the widespread use of fuels, BTEX compounds (benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, m-, o-, and p-xylene) and MTBE (methyl tertiary-butyl ether) are frequently detected groundwater contaminants, with releases occurring during their production, transportation and storage (Baehr et al., 1999; Deeb et al., 2000; Squillace et al., 1996). MTBE has received considerable attention in recent times as it migrates much more quickly through the soil than most of the petroleum distillates due to its high water solubility (up to 51 g L−1, USEPA, 2004). Its presence in the environment is considered as a health and drinking water problem and classifies MTBE as a possible human carcinogen (Johnson et al., 2000). MTBE is relatively resistant to biological degradation under anaerobic conditions (Moreels et al., 2006), but several studies have shown a biodegradability under aerobic conditions (Deeb et al., 2000; Ferreira et al., 2006; Schmidt et al., 2004).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane and toluene are both mentioned as components of BTEX compounds, which are common groundwater contaminants. However, the text primarily focuses on the environmental impact and degradation of MTBE, with no direct interaction or specific relationship discussed between 2-methoxy-2-methylpropane and toluene. Their mention is more about their classification as contaminants rather than any functional or chemical relationship.
